channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Grow Your Karma with a Job that Does Good! Perl role in Australia
item.description: Not all jobs are created equal. Sure, most pay the bills, but some do more. They impart a sense of purpose; when you log out at day’s end, it’s with the satisfaction that you are part of something bigger, something more important than yourself. You’ve left the world a little better than you found it, and isn’t that what life is really about?

item.title: Join Our Merry Band of Perl Programmers. Perl in Belarus
item.description: Looking for Perl developers with a strong background in Modern Perl – you should be comfortable with Moose and PSGI/Plack, and a solid grounding in using Perl’s testing tools. Our client has opened a new office in Belarus. This role offers a unique opportunity to join an established company in a new space.

item.title: Cooking Up Something Good. Perl role in London
item.description: If your mouth is watering at the thought of joining this dynamic team and you’re a senior Perl programmer with a solid understanding of Go programming languages, they just might set a place for you at the table.

item.title: That’s a Big Sandbox! Perl role in London
item.description: The client is interested in anyone with experience building web apps in Perl, using one of the major Perl frameworks. If you’re a crack-hand with Catalyst, a Mojolicious master, or a distinguished Dance, they want you. You’ll be deploying apps your work to AWS, so experience would be handy, and the company’s big on testing, so they’d like you to know your way around Test::More.

item.title: Not All Heroes Wear Capes. Perl in Vienna
item.description: Our client takes the legwork out of the hunt for the best bargain, offering one of the largest product and price comparison platforms in German-speaking countries. They’re looking for a heroic Perl programmer to develop and deliver quality content and all the info users need to find their gadgets for the right price.

item.title: The Perl and Raku Conference in the Cloud 2021
item.description: Online 9-11 June 2021.

item.title: German Perl Workshop 2021
item.description: It will take place online between March 24-26 2021. The private ticket will be cheaper (EUR 30). People who register in time and transfer the participation fee, will get exclusive extras.

item.description: Thursday, March 4, 2021

item.title: Rex
item.description: Ferki taught me a few things about Rex and now we are planning a live session in which he is going to teach me a lot more. Follow my Twitch channel to get notified.

item.title: Add FAQ entry to MetaCPAN
item.description: Some of the distributions on CPAN are marked as 'looking for maintainer'. Test::Class had it on so I asked for it and became the maintainer of that module. Then came the question, how can I remove the notifiaction about the need for a maintainer. In this video you will see how to add this explanation to the FAQ of MetaCPAN and then how to add a link from the notification banner to this entry in the FAQ.

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report;
StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: Accept a payment with perl
item.description: In this episode, you'll learn how to accept a one time payment with stripe-perl aka Net::Stripe.

item.description: Celebrating the 100th week of The Weekly Challenge.

item.description: Please find all the talks recorded at the recently concluded FOSDEM event.

item.title: Carp::Always to find the source of the problem
item.description: In #Perl warn and die tell us where a problem was noticed. carp and croak tell us where they were created.

item.title: List::GroupBy
item.description: List::GroupBy is a small module converting a list of hashes to some multi-level hash tabele. This is a code-reading video.

item.description: Luis one-liner is easily decodable and does the job.

item.description: Simon came up with cryptic one-liner. Decoding one-liner is always fun.

item.description: It is pretty evident that Roger didn't like Perl one-liner. He came up with detailed solution as always.

item.description: Luca sharing his Raku skill and presented the Raku magic.

item.description: Lance promoting TDD with great precision. Thanks for the kind words.

item.title: Perl weekly challenge 100
item.description: James turned out to be a big fan of Perl one-liner. I loved his code.

item.description: I enjoy the story behind the solution. The solution itself is so trivial.

item.description: Dave's contribution is always verbose and blog explaining every minute details.

item.description: Adam also showing his regex skill while dealing with this week task.

item.description: Abigail use of map to read input numbers is interesting.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 100
item.description: Aaron becoming master of one-liner in Perl. Always fun to decode his code.

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 100
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Fun Time" and "Triangle Sum" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 101
item.description: Welcome a new week with a couple of fun tasks "Pack a Spiral" and "Origin-containing Triangle". If you are new to the weekly challenge then why not join us and have fun every week. For more information, please read FAQ page.

item.title: rt.cpan.org is staying
item.description: Ricardo shared the good news with us.

item.title: How to install a Perl environment with a single command?
item.description: This video demonstrates how to use ActiveState Platform’s CLI interface, the State Tool to install Perl environments generally. For purposes of this demo, we compare two web frameworks: Mojolicious versus Dancer. Take a look!

item.title: #500 - TPF and TRF
item.description:
Hi there

What an honour to present the 500th edition of the Perl Weekly newsletter. Thank you Gabor Szabo.

Let's begin the week with the good news, rt.cpan.org is staying. You can find more details here.

Andrew Shitov raised an issue with regard to have separate entity "The Raku Foundation". Feel free to share your views on the subject.

Did you know Cor is now given new name, Corinna?

Curtis Poe recently requested the general public to share their views of Corinna being in the Perl core. Please do checkout the wiki page

This week, we celebrated the 100th week of The Weekly Challenge. I even created YouTube Video to thank Team PWC for their support and encouragements.

After a long time, I got the opportunity to Pair Programming. Thanks to my friend, Julien Fiegehenn, we spent an hour and half long session and got MooX::Clone released to CPAN in the end. It all started when I was working on my latest project Design Patterns using Modern Perl, more specifically, Prototype Design Pattern where I was looking for clean interface to create clone of Moo object.

Zum ersten Mal teilen wir Blogs in nicht-englischer Sprache. Ich hoffe es würde unseren deutschen Lesern gefallen.

Enjoy the rest of the newsletter.
